status_notes: Case Closed. Case Resolved. BWSC is separating the drain and sewer lines in many of the streets in South Boston. The city acknowledges that this has been a hardship for the citizens of South Boston. However, when the project is done, South Boston will have entirely new water, sewer, and drain infrastructure. This is a great benefit to the citizens of South Boston. When all of the work has been completed and the streets are paved, emergency leaks related to water and sewer will be eliminated. This project is on a timeline and that is why we allowed them to work. The city apologizes for the inconvenience. Any questions related to the project, you can call Boston Water and Sewer at 617-989-7000 and ask for construction. You can also contact my office if need be. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office. 617-438-8517 Cell.

status_notes: Case Closed. Case Resolved. Langdon St is the only street that has the right of way at this intersection. Both Roswell and Cedric Sts intersect Langdon as T-intersections, which, by law, are always stop controlled whether signage is present or not. After performing a site visit, it was determined that though these two intersections are closely spaced, there is enough of an offset that a driver should not assume that he can continue across Langdon without stopping. Additionally, the presence of parking on the southern side of Roswell and the northern side of Cedric accentuates this offset.

status_notes: Case Closed. Case Resolved. Engineer performed a site visit and noted that the signalized crossing at Centre Street appears to be the closest and safest route to Shawmut Station from the other side of Dorchester Ave. Based on the high volumes of vehicles on Dorchester Ave in this area throughout the day, if a crosswalk were installed it may be difficult for a crosser to identify a suitable gap in traffic. Additionally, there are concerns that a crosswalk may lead to a false sense of safety at this location. No pedestrians were viewed crossing in the area during the time of the site visit. Engineer did not hear back from constituent after a request for additional information.
description: Is there any way we could explore installing a crosswalk at Dot Ave and Mather or at a nearby cross street? Mather is the most direct road to Shawmut Station and those living across Dot Ave have no good crossing area without having to go significantly out of our way in walking to the station. This has become a pretty major safety issue for pedestrian residents on a fast moving street like Dot Ave.

status_notes: Case Closed. Case Resolved. On behalf of PWD, I would like to apologize to this particular Constituent. I  (Gary Thomas) am a Foreman for dist 2/10 Highland st yard and well aware who the private contractor is. I would just like to ensure the Constituent that in future snow events, every precaution will be taken to make sure this problem will never occur again. I personally will speak to the gentleman on this route and tell him to face his blade away from the Constituent's driveway every time he makes his passes. The problem has been highly taken into consideration and all measures will be taken to eliminate it. Inspectors will also be made aware of the problem and constantly will monitor the area and make sure the contractor does not keep making the mistake. Any problems or concerns, please contact me at 617-635-7521 (Gary) and I personally will handle it. Once again, PWD would like to apologize and the issue is noted and will be resolved.
description:
my property is located on a hill, just after an intersection. snow plows will routinely turn left on sheldon, head downhill on prospect and pass my home. 
there is one driver that i believe is a private contractor in a black unmarked truck with no visible license plate  that takes that left turn and purposely empties his blade directly in my driveway.
he will return multiple times during the night to repeat this act, after i have spent hours chopping up the giant ice blocks to clear the entrance to my driveway.
i have tried to get a picture of this driver and the truck but i usually wake up to the sound of his blade hitting the pavement and i get to the door in time to see him turn right on sycamore street and my driveway is blocked with a new delivery of ice.
in the past, he has almost hit my while i was shoveling my sidewalk, and will often turn right on sheldon if he sees me watching for him which makes it difficult to ge a picture
the mayors hotline has connected me to the DPW yard in the past. but all anyone will tell me is they have no way of knowing which private contractor is on my street.
this has been going on for several years. I am 52 years old. hardly a senior citizen but also not a 20 year old with the energy to constantly shovel ice blocks out of the driveway.
Im looking for any advise or suggestions you might offer

status_notes: Case Closed. Case Resolved. National Grid is installing a new gas main.  The city encourages this type of capital upgrade work.  It will eliminate future emergency repairs. National Grid has to install the gas main first.  Once the main has been installed, then all service connections can be made. If the city were to make National Grid pave to grade each day's trench work,  it would cause multiple seams along the trench.  More importantly, every service connection needs to be cut into the trench.  If we were to pave the trench every day,  this would result in 2 by 2 patches inside the trench area, resulting in a very poor final product. In order to have the best final paving, the city allows the utility company to leave the trench down low until all service connections are made and then pave the trench all at once, resulting in a smooth, level final trench repair.  Service laterals are topped within 24 hours of excavation. What the constituent is observing is the trench left down low in preparation for one continuous final paving operation. There are signs posted informing the public that there is active construction work, and that the trench is uneven until completion. The work is scheduled to be completed sometime in mid-January. The city apologizes for the inconvenience this necessary work has caused. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office. 617-438-8517 Cell. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951 Office.

description:
Someone's getting coal on their stocking! I asked for Marion Street between White and Monmouth in Eastie to be cleaned in case # 101000989879.  Well, surprise!  Someone in public works should have a nose longer than Pinocchio by now.  The crap on the street by the curb and on the sidewalk on the odd side of the street (3-21 Marion St) survived the two snow storms in tact. I've lived in developing countries with open sewers and the trash here looks more vile.  Please be sure that the cotton headed ninny-muggins who claimed to have "swept" up the dog feces, trash, empty cat food dishes, etc actually does it.

Merry Christmas.
